questions.text: Which of the following nerves supplies the muscle that is involved in the moment given below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Spinal accessory nerve

Explanation:

  • The movement shown in the image is shrugging, which is carried out by the trapezius muscles and supplied by the spinal accessory nerve.
  • Lesion of the accessory nerve or paralysis of the trapezius leads to drooping of shoulders and difficulty in shrugging and weakness of overhead abduction.

Trapezius

  • Origin: Occipital bone and cervicothoracic spine
  • Insertion: Scapula Bone and Clavicle
  • Three sets of fiber:
    • Upper: Insertion on clavicle (lateral 1/3posterior side)
    • Middle: Insertion on acromion process anteriorly
    • Lower: Insertion on the spine of the scapula
  • Nerve Supply: Accessory nerve (CN XI)
  • Action:
    • Elevation (upper fiber) and depression (lower fiber)
    • Retractor (Midline)
    • Rotates the Glenoid cavity superiorly.

Long thoracic nerve (Option B): Supplies serratus anterior, which is responsible for scapular protraction (not related to the given movement).

Spinal branch of axillary nerve (Option C): Supplies deltoid and teres minor, involved in shoulder abduction and lateral rotation.

Radial nerve (Option D): Innervates triceps, wrist extensors, and is involved in elbow extension and wrist extension.

questions.text: What is the action of the muscle shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Retracts the scapula

Explanation:

  • The muscle identified in the image is the rhomboid major.
  • Originating from the C7 and T1 vertebrae, it inserts along the medial border of the scapula.
  • Primarily functioning as a retractor, the rhomboid major also plays roles in elevating the scapula and rotating it to depress the glenoid cavity.

3- Lower fibers: depress scapula.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) a-2, b-4, c-3, d-1

Correct Option: a-2, b-4, c-3, d-1

2. Flexion at shoulder

b. Supraspinatus

4. Abduction at shoulder

1. Extension at shoulder

 

Muscles of the Anterior Axioappendicular Region

Muscle

Origin

Insertion

Nerve Supply

Actions

Pectoralis Major
  • Anterior surface of the medial two-thirds of the clavicle
  • Front of the manubrium and sternum up to the 6th costal cartilages
  • Second to sixth costal cartilages and sternal end of the 6th rib
  • Aponeurosis of the external oblique muscle

Lateral lip of the bicipital groove of the humerus (via bilaminar tendon)

Medial and lateral pectoral nerves
  • Adducts and medially rotates the arm
  • Flexes the arm (clavicular part)
  • Extends the flexed arm against resistance (sternocostal part)

 

Pectoralis Minor

3rd, 4th, and 5th ribs near the costochondral junction

Medial border and upper surface of the coracoid process

Medial and lateral pectoral nerves
  • Protracts the scapula
  • Lowers the point of the shoulder

Subclavius

First rib at the costochondral junction

Subclavian groove on the middle third of the clavicle

Nerve to subclavius (from upper trunk of brachial plexus)
  • Stabilizes the clavicle during shoulder movements
  • Protects axillary vessels and brachial plexus

 

Serratus Anterior

Eight digitations from the upper 8 ribs and fascia over the intercostal muscles

Costal surface of the medial border of the scapula

Long thoracic nerve (C5, C6, C7)
  • Protracts scapula
  • Rotates scapula upward for arm abduction beyond 90 degrees
  • Stabilizes the scapula during weight-bearing activities
  • Assists in forced inspiration

Muscles of the posterior Axioappendicular Region

Muscle

Origin

Insertion

Nerve Supply

Actions

Trapezius
  • Medial one-third of the superior nuchal line of the skull
  • External occipital protuberance
  • Ligamentum nuchae
  • Spinous processes of C7 to T12 vertebrae
  • Corresponding supraspinous ligaments
  • Upper fibers: Posterior border of the lateral one-third of the clavicle
  • Middle fibers: Medial margin of the acromion and upper lip of the spine of the scapula
  • Lower fibers: Apex of a triangular area at the medial end of the spine of the scapula (intervening bursa)

Spinal accessory nerve (CN XI) and proprioceptive fibers from C3 and C4.
  • Upper fibers: Elevate the scapula (shoulder shrugging), extend the neck (bilaterally)
  • Middle fibers: Retract the scapula
  • Lower fibers: Rotate the scapula upward, aiding arm abduction beyond 90 degrees
  • Trapezius with rhomboids: Retract scapula and tilt glenoid inferiorly.
  • Trapezius with serratus anterior: Overhead abduction and tilt glenoid superiorly.
  • All fibers together: Stabilize the scapula during arm movements

 

Latissimus Dorsi
  • Posterior one-third of the outer lip of the iliac crest
  • Posterior layer of lumbar fascia (connecting to lumbar and sacral spines)
  • Spinous processes of T7 to T12
  • Lower four ribs
  • Inferior angle of the scapula

Fibers twist to insert into the floor of the intertubercular sulcus of the humerus, wrapping around the lower border of the teres major.

Thoracodorsal nerve (C6, C7, C8).
  • Extends, adducts, and medially rotates the arm (e.g., swimming, climbing)
  • Assists in forceful expiration (e.g., coughing, sneezing

Levator Scapulae

Transverse processes of C1 to C4 vertebrae

Superior angle and upper part of the medial border of the scapula

Dorsal scapular nerve (C5) and branches from C3 and C4

Elevates and stabilizes the scapula during arm movements.

 

Rhomboid Minor

Lower part of ligamentum nuchae and spinous processes of C7 and T1

Medial border of the scapula at the base of the triangular area at the root of the spine.

Dorsal scapular nerve (C5)

Retracts and stabilizes the scapula.

 

Rhomboid Major

Spinous processes of T2 to T5 and supraspinous ligaments

Medial border of the scapula, below the root of the spine

Dorsal scapular nerve (C5)

Retracts and stabilizes the scapula.

questions.text: The movements at the _______ joint permit a person to look to the right and left
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Atlanto-axial joint:

The Atlanto-axial joint is formed between the atlas (C1 vertebra) and the axis (C2 vertebra) in the spine. This joint is responsible for rotational movements of the head. The axis (C2) has a peg-like structure called the dens or odontoid process, which fits into the atlas (C1), allowing for rotation. Therefore, the Atlanto-axial joint permits the specific movements required for looking to the right and left.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Atlanto-occipital joint

The Atlanto-occipital joint permits flexion and extension movements of the head, like nodding. It's mainly for tilting the head forward and backward, rather than side-to-side rotation.

 Option C - C2-C3 intervertebral joint

The C2-C3 intervertebral joint permits flexion, extension, lateral bending, and some degree of rotation, but sideways rotation is mainly handled by the Atlanto-axial joint, not C2-C3.

Option D - C3-C4 intervertebral joint

The C3-C4 joint, similar to C2-C3, allows neck movements like flexion, extension, lateral bending, and some degree of rotation. However, it's not directly involved in sideways rotational movements.

questions.text: Retraction of the scapula is primarily done by?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Trapezius

  • Trapezius: The trapezius muscle is a large muscle that covers the upper back and neck. It plays a key role in the movement and stabilization of the scapula. The middle and lower fibers of the trapezius muscle primarily perform scapular retraction, which involves pulling the scapula backward toward the spine.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Serratus anterior: The serratus anterior muscle protracts and rotates the scapula, stabilizing it against the rib cage. However, it doesn't directly retract the scapula at the sternoclavicular joint.

Option C - Subscapularis: The subscapularis muscle, part of the rotator cuff, sits on the front of the scapula. It internally rotates the humerus and stabilizes the shoulder joint but doesn't aid in scapular retraction.

Option D - Supraspinatus: The supraspinatus muscle, part of the rotator cuff, is located on the back of the scapula. It helps initiate shoulder abduction but isn't mainly responsible for scapular retraction.

questions.text: What is the cause of scapular winging?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Serratus anterior:

  • Serratus anterior: The serratus anterior muscle is primarily responsible for stabilizing the scapula against the thoracic wall. When the serratus anterior muscle is paralyzed or weakened, it can lead to winging of the scapula. This muscle is especially important for maintaining proper scapular position during movements such as pushing, pulling, and reaching. Hence, option B is correct.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Trapezius: The trapezius muscle stabilizes and moves the scapula, but its paralysis typically doesn't cause scapular winging.

Option C - Latissimus dorsi: The latissimus dorsi muscle assists in various shoulder movements but is typically not associated with scapular winging, even when weakened or paralyzed.

Option D - Pectoralis major: The pectoralis major muscle aids shoulder movements but usually doesn't cause scapular winging if paralyzed.

questions.text: Ligamentum flavum has high levels of:-
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Elastin fibres:

The ligamentum flavum connects adjacent vertebrae, crucial for spinal stability and flexibility. Elastin fibers within it provide elasticity, enabling stretching and recoiling to maintain stability during movement. Its yellowish color comes from high elastin levels.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Type 1 collagen: Type 1 collagen is abundant in tendons, ligaments, and bone, but the ligamentum flavum contains lower levels compared to other connective tissues.

Option B - Type 2 collagen: Type 2 collagen is primarily found in hyaline cartilage, like in joint articular cartilage and vertebral discs, but it's not notably present in the ligamentum flavum.

Option C - Reticular fibers: Reticular fibers, composed of type 3 collagen, form mesh-like networks in organs like lymph nodes and spleen, but they're not notably present in the ligamentum flavum.

questions.text: Which of the following is normally seen in lumbar spine?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Lordosis:

  • Lordosis: Lordosis refers to the inward curvature of the spine, creating a concave shape. In the lumbar spine, lordosis is considered a normal anatomical feature. It helps to maintain the balance and proper alignment of the spine, allowing for efficient weight distribution and movement.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Scoliosis: Scoliosis is an abnormal sideways curvature of the spine, typically found in the thoracic or thoracolumbar regions, not the lumbar spine.

Option B - Kyphosis: Kyphosis is an excessive forward curvature of the spine, often causing a rounded or hunched-back appearance. While normal in the thoracic spine, it's uncommon in the lumbar spine.

Option D - Recurvatum: Recurvatum is hyperextension of a joint, seen notably in the knee but not typically in the lumbar spine.
